1. Increased, strengthened and expanded number of and capacity of human resources for government lead actors in understanding basic conflict handling mechanisms 2. Technical criteria developed to determine flashpoint conflicts using objective data collection and analysis 3. Government structures and systems developed for government lead actors for workload management and coordination 4. Increase in number and expansion in capacity of recovery/development activities in project areas reflecting enhanced conflict sensitivity 5. Acquired conflict handling knowledge and skills are reflected in government lead actors’ design and approach to targeting flashpoint conflicts 6. Increase in numbers and diversification of key stakeholders engaged by government lead actors in support of peace processes 7. Increase in number of coordinated linkages/projects/activities between recovery interventions and peace-led government processes 8. Inclusion of conflict sensitive practices in outcomes of recovery projects linked to peace processes

comment.narrative: • Government lead actors have received limited/ no technical training in conflict handling. • Government lead actors have received limited/ no institutional development support. • Targeted flashpoint conflicts determined based on political (not technical) criteria • Low levels of internal and external coordination by government lead actors with key stakeholders. • Limited range of approaches utilized to analyze and address flashpoint conflicts by government lead actors. • Peace conferences carried out as ‘one-off’ events with insufficient preparation/follow-up • Low levels of engagement of women and youth and other key stakeholders in government-led peace processes • Peace agreements achieved with some degree of political pressure • Government-led peace processes lack coordinated support to address identified causes of conflict • Post-conflict community needs identified without technical review or prioritization • Post-conflict recovery projects not implemented in conflict sensitive manner • Critical resources and lessons learned regarding conflict handling / conflict sensitivity not shared among key stakeholders

Output 1:Government and community – led peace building initiatives supported to promote stability, inter-communal reconciliation and peaceful coexistence • Target: 3 mechanisms for mediation and consensus building with core functions clearly defined • Target: 3 mechanisms for mediation and consensus building with responsibilities and core functions clearly assigned • Target: 3 mechanisms for mediation and consensus building with budgets allocated • Target: 3 mechanisms for mediation and consensus building with action plans being implemented • Target: Increased capacity of Government partners to promote stability, inter-communal reconciliation and peaceful co-existence (10%) Output 2: Current and future local flashpoint conflicts are mitigated through inclusive peace processes. • Target: 70% of JCRP supported peace process holding after 12 months. • Target: 100 % of peace conferences carried out with the equal representation of the total number of conflicting parties. • Target: 50% of peace building training workshops, peace conference or dialogue participants from vulnerable groups (women, youth, elderly, persons with disabilities). Output 3: Local stakeholders are linked to high-level peace processes through dialogue and dissemination of information. • Target: 3 briefing session and dialogues conducted between local level and high level peace actors with the support of JCRP

Output 1: Government and community – led peace building initiatives supported to promote stability, inter-communal reconciliation and peaceful coexistence • 3 Mechanisms are in place; the PC in BNS, the RPCM in WKS and the SPPCC in SKS (Source: Government Decrees) • The PC does have a budget allocated but the SPPCC and RPCM do not as yet. • All 3 peacebuilding mechanisms have action plans in place. • Repeat Assessments of Government partners perceived capacities to promote stability, inter-communal reconciliation and peaceful co-existence are due to take place in Q4 2015, the PC has 10% increase in graded score.
Output 2: Current and future local flashpoint conflicts are mitigated through inclusive peace processes. • 94% (or 16/17) of JCRP supported peace processes continued to hold after 12 months (Source: State Peacebuilding Mechanisms) •100 % of peace conferences carried out with the equal representation of the total number of conflicting parties. • One peace conference was held in June in SKS with 50% active participation from vulnerable groups.
Output 3: Local stakeholders are linked to high-level peace processes through dialogue and dissemination of information. • Three dialogues sessions between local level and high level peace actors with the support of JCRP were conducted in 2015: 1) 88 community peacebuilders, representatives from State-level mechanisms, and CSOs took part in the Peace Ambassador Forum held in Khartoum, March 2015, 2) during 3 days consultations in Khartoum in May 2015, more than 35 community peacebuilders from SKS, WKS, Abyei, BLN, and Darfur took part in a dialogue facilitation session and peacebuilding consultation at the University of Khartoum, 3) in September 2015, more than 400 people from SKS, WKS, BNS, Abyei and Darfur participated in the Sudan Peace Symposium (SPS) co-organized by UNDP/JCRP and the University of Khartoum. Plan to sustain the scheme in place 2.1 Number of young qualified graduates selected, trained and deployed disaggregated by gender and state. 2.2 % of volunteers satisfied with relevance and quality of training provided and applying at the field. 2.3 % of deployed volunteers who successfully graduate and receive certificates (disaggregated by gender and state) 3.1 Number of community members trained and Percentage of community members who feel enabled by training disaggregated by type of training, state, age and gender 3.2 Number of start-up micro-grants awarded and number of small businesses successfully started via the micro-grants disaggregated by state, gender and age of the business owner. 3.3 Number of small businesses successfully progressing 6 months after the start-up, disaggregated by gender of the business owner and age. 3.4 Number of environmental campaigns and cleanup exercises organised. 4.1 Number of graduation ceremonies and job fairs organised disaggregated by state; 4.2 % of deployed Youth Volunteers who successfully graduated disaggregated by state and gender. 4.3 % of deployed youth Volunteers employed after 6 months of training and graduation disaggregated by gender and state.

comment.narrative: Baseline: Darfur Youth unemployment estimated = 40%

1.1 The Youth Volunteer Scheme reviewed through one independent evaluation and one baseline survey; 1.2 90% of PCU and SPCU staff feel capacitated and confident doing their jobs; 1.3 A sustainability strategy and plan for the Youth Volunteer scheme developed and adopted. 2.1. 80 youth volunteers from Phase 1 selected, trained on additional subjects and deployed; 100 new qualified young graduates selected, trained and deployed, disaggregated by gender and state; 80 Volunteers from phase 1 o 30Volunteers in SED (40 % female) o 30 young graduates in ND (40 % female) o 20 young graduates in WCD (40 % female). 100 New Volunteers o 45 young graduates in SED (40 % female). o 35 young graduates in ND (40 % female). o 20 young graduates in WCD (40 % female). 2.2 At least 90% of candidates satisfied with relevance and quality of the training provided and applying knowledge and skills at the field; 2.3 At least 90% of new youth volunteers deployed of successfully graduate of which 40% are female. 3.1 Approximately 5,000 (2000M/ 3000F) community members trained; of which 80% community members are satisfied with quality of training . Business Management Training (including entrepreneurship, ASCA management, business idea development) o SED: 1500 (600M/900F) o ND: 1,300 (520M/780) o WCD: 1,050 (420M/ 630F) Environment and Natural Resources o SED: 500 ( 200M/ 300F) o ND: 400 (160M/240F) o WCD: 250 (100M/150F) 3.2 At least 350 micro-grants awarded and 350 businesses successfully started/expanded via micro-grants; (100 in SED, 150 in ND, 100 in WCD) of which 50% are owned by women and 30% youth. 3.3 At least 270 of the small businesses started (60%) are successfully progressing 3 months after the start-up of which 60% are women and 30% youth. 3.4 At least 3 2 Environmental campaign and clean-up exercises organized under phase 1 (1 in El Fasher, 1 Geneina and 1 Nyala) 4.1 At least 3 Graduation ceremonies and jobs fairs organised (1 in SED, 1 in ND, 1 in WCD)

1.1 The independent evaluation has been completed and the baseline survey is ongoing and will be finalized by the end of the year. 1.2 One PCU and 3 SPCUs were reactivated and are now operational. A perception survey with regards to the capacity and confidence of the staff will be conducted at the end of 2015. 1.3 The strategy is currently being developed by a consultant and will be finalized by the end of the year. 2.1. 59 youth from Phase 1 have been selected, trained and deployed. 150 new qualified young graduates selected and are under trained and deploy o 59 Volunteers from phase 1 (47% female) o 150 New volunteers (40% female) 2.2 Training is still ongoing and the evaluation results will be analyzed at the end of training 2.3 The training of the new volunteers is still ongoing and the volunteers are to be deployed in 2016 3.1 The training of the community members will be carried out in 2016 3.2 The micro-grants and business establishment will take place in 2016 3.3 The micro-grants and business establishment will take place in 2016 3.4 The environmental campaign will take place on 5 December, the International Volunteers Day 4.1 One graduation ceremony has been organized. The remaining two as well as the job fairs will be organized in 2016 4.2 This result will be measured at the end of the project in 2016 4.3 This result will be measured at the end of the project in 2016

1.1) The Youth Volunteer Scheme is run independently by the three SPCUs and one PCU 1.2) 90% of PCU and SPCU staff feel they are capable of doing their job 1.3) A sustainability strategy for the Youth Volunteers scheme is developed and adopted. 2.1) 60 youth volunteers from Phase I trained on additional subjects and deployed for follow-up activities 2.2) At least 80% of candidates satisfied with relevance and quality of training provided 2.3) 150 new youth volunteers are trained and deployed 3.1) At least 200 community members gained sound knowledge on sustainable establishment of small business and 80 % of them submit own loan proposals 3.2) At least 135 start-up grants/loans awarded for projects (3 winners/ community: Total 45 communities) and at least 200 ASCA groups established 3.3) At least 10,000 community members trained on business and environmental topics and 85% feel the trainings was beneficial 4.1) At least 150 youth volunteers and 50 trained community youth attend the job fairs 4.2) 90 % of deployed volunteers successfully graduated and received certificates 4.3) 40% of 150 youth volunteers (self-) employed 12 months after their assignment

Targets achieved. 1.1 The structure of the volunteer scheme was reviewed where the Project Coordination Unit (PCU) has been abolished. The Project re-activated and established State Project Coordination Units (SPCUs) in El Fasher, Nyala, Geneina and Zalingei. UNDP plays the role of the Project Coordination Unit (PCU) and each SPCU is treated as an independent implementing partner and directly link with UNDP. This has improved coordination, implementation and institutionalisation within each state. 1.2 UNDP team supported the capacity development of SPCUs through weekly coaching, mentoring, and on-the-job training as well as customised trainings. According to the end of year survey, 100 % of staff feel they are capable of doing their jobs as SPCU staff. 1.3 A sustainability strategy and plan for the full independence and institutionalisation of the scheme has been developed. The strategy is currently under review by state stakeholders for finalisation. The strategy is expected to be adopted after the final review by stakeholders. The plan has provided further guidance on the future institutional arrangements necessary to sustain the scheme. 2.1 59 (54%M/46%F) from phase (I) were selected and given refresher training and redeployed to 47 communities in 5 Darfur states. They conducted and completed their monitoring and follow-up activities at the community level in January 2016. 46 of the volunteers were Business Volunteers (M: 29, F: 17) and 13 whereas Environment Volunteers (M: 3; F: 10). 2.2 Training evaluation survey results indicate that 97.6% of trainees were satisfied with relevance and quality of the training provided and applied knowledge and skills at the field. 2.3 150 new (58%M/42%F) youth volunteers were selected and trained for 4 weeks and deployed to 45 target communities in five Darfur states where they successfully completed the nine-month. These include 90 Business volunteers (M: 53, F: 37) and 45 Environmental volunteers (M: 19, F: 26) 15 Senior v

Four Village Savings and Loan Associations (VLSAs) have been reactivated and trained on basic management and book-keeping in Central Darfur representing 80% of the overall target. A total of 60 members (all women) have since started savings and meeting on regular basis. 1.3) Target on track. Fourteen value chain related producer groups were formed and currently functioning during the year with a total of 3,375 members of which (50% female). 1.4) Target on track. In total, 12 different infrastructures were established/ rehabilitated developed during the reporting period. 2.2) Target achieved. During the year, a total of 12,000 community members (66% women) benefited from the infrastructure developed/rehabilitated 2.3) Target achieved. All the 12 community assets (100%) established/rehabilitated are linked to markets and value chains and this translates to 100% of the developed community assets. 2.4) Target achieved. A total of 540 people (52% women) were employed in temporary labour intensive schemes during the rehabilitation of 6 hand-pumps in Abudowai, Kuromandi, Kateila and Hajir village (Kubum locality). Some additional 300 people (63% female) were engaged on voluntary basis during the rehabilitation of the dam. 2.5) Target achieved. According to a perception survey conducted, 72% of the people in targeted areas have improved perceptions of social cohesion within the twelve months of the project. 3.1) Target achieved. description.narrative: Darfur Field Offices Operations.
This project was set up to complement the new Darfur Field Office Structure in Geneina.
independent political entity
Strengthened ER operational and coordination capacity (including repositioning capacity) of UNDP and Partners.
seat of a first-order administrative division

- RRR Sector operating effectively and improved coordination of ER activities - Knowledge and skills of UNDP and partners on ER enhanced through technical expertise and training - ER priorities reflected consistently across different humanitarian sectors and a coherent plan for the Sudan HWP strategic objectives of resilience and durable solutions in place

comment.narrative: - ER-gap Sector established, named the Recovery, Return and Reintegration (RRR) Sector - Capacity UNDP to meet expectations as sector lead nationally and in Darfur needs to be strengthened - Cross-sectoral prioritization of ER remains weak and uneven within current Humanitarian Planning and Coordination

Output 1: 1.1 At least 5 sectors have ER priorities reflected in them 1.2 Strategy paper on ER, resilience and durable solutions developed for Sudan 1.3 Twelve RRR sector coordination meetings conducted in Khartoum and sector established in Darfur 1.4 Four UNDP dedicated staff for RRR recruited and UNDP’s capacity as sector lead strengthened

Activity Result 1: Target achieved. In the 2015 Humanitarian response plan (HRP), 5 sectors have reflected ER approaches in their humanitarian sector plans and during consultations in preparation of the 2016 HRP all sectors have agreed to reflect ER approaches in their sector plans and all are aiming to identify better linkages between humanitarian response and longer-term recovery in Sudan. However the overall 2016 HRP has been delayed and is not yet finalized. Activity Result 2: Target achieved. The RRR sector has build capacity in key staff from Humanitarian Aid Commission and Darfur Regional Authorities in support of a national-owned Durable Solutions (DS) Strategy for IDPs in Sudan in line with international standards. Strategies for ER DS have been developed and fed into the 2016 HRP consultation meetings. Activity Result 3: Target on track -The RRR sector has conducted 11 sector meetings in Khartoum and has planned one more meeting for December 2015. Due to delay in recruitment, the sector in Darfur has not been established. However, consultation meetings have taken place in Darfur in preparation of the establishment of the RRR sector. Activity Result 4: Target achieved - Three UNDP dedicated staff have been recruited. As per the plan, the fourth staff, for UNDP's capacity to lead ER coordination, has been realized through the short-term recruitment of an Early Recovery Advisor to the HC/RC

1.1 At least 5 sectors have ER priorities reflected in them 1.2 Strategy paper on ER, resilience and durable solutions developed for Sudan 1.3 Twelve RRR sector coordination meetings conducted in Khartoum and sector established in Darfur 1.4 Four UNDP dedicated staff for RRR recruited and UNDP’s capacity as sector lead strengthened

1.1 Target achieved. All sectors have some kind of ER priorities reflected in their sector response plan and 47% of all HRP interventions can be classified as early recovery or resilience building. 1.2 Target on track. Several documents have been developed and are currently under review including a Protracted Displaced Strategy to be mainstreamed under the HRP as well as national-owned Durable Solutions strategy for IDPs 1.3 Target achieved. 11 meetings have been conducted in Khartoum (one is pending for December) and the sector is established in 3 states in Darfur. At the Darfur level, some 6 meetings have been held to date 1.4 Target achieved. Three staff under the RRR plus one 50% staff have been deployed.

title.narrative: Local Governance Develop. Public Expenditure Mangement

description.narrative: Strengthen capacities for local governance and strategic planning to entrench decentralization and actualize devolution in Eastern Sudan

The progrm will strengthen the overall governance and public expenditure management systems at the State/local level in order to enhnace the State Governments’ capacity for resource planning and public service deliver
second-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
Accountability - local government finance

1. Locality plans linked to the state Strategic Plan 2. The State budget linked to planning framework 3. State Macro-economic policy formulated 4. Enactment of state financial laws 5. Amendment to state Local Government laws to clarify fiscal roles between Federal, state and localities 6. State administrative, accounting and finance regulations established 7. Institutionalized budget policy analysis and management function 8. Planning office established 9. MoLG coordinates capacity development for localities 10. Roles for public planning and expenditure management clarified 11. Number of laws reviewed 12. Number of policies reviewed 13. Level of harmonisation in institutional mandates and functions 14. Regular rhythm of policy dialogue under the Forum; 15. Regular rhythm of engagement with donors; 16. implementation structures established 17. Key Staff Recruited 18. Implementation agreements secured 19. Programme financing secured

comment.narrative: 1. GFS classification has only been introduced in RSS 2. all the three states do not have an institutionalised budget policy function and the budgets are not guided by macro-economic analysis 3. revenue predictions are inadequate and unreliable (up to 60% shortfalls) severely affecting the predictability of budget implementation 4. None of the 3 state has the required laws and regulations for financial and procurement management 5. Gaps in fiscal relations between state and local government level leading to overlapping or confusing roles in revenue and expenditure management and accountability 6. Gaps in fiscal relations between state and federal government leading to confusing roles in fiscal policy management 7. Institutional roles for budget policy analysis and management are not clearly defined leading to overlap and gaps in implementation 8. there are no locality planning units in the states of Kassala and Gedaref while in RSS only 5 of the 10 localities have locality plans 9. in all the 3 states the public expenditure policy management function is lacking 10. organisational and financial management skills are low across the states leading to planning and budget formulation 11. lack of a coordinated legal, policy and institutional reform programme; lack of policy coordination mechanism; overlapping legal frameworks and institutional mandates; low public service out put 12. Eastern Sudan Forum has not worked as a forum in mobilising 3 states towards objectives of the ESPA 13. Programme implementation structures not established

1. at least 2 training programmes in core local governance functions 2. legislative forums conducted and 2 strategies reviewed 3. at least 120 staff 80 males and 40 female on planning) trained within the planning department in the state ministries of finance in the East and South Kordofan 4. Number of 60 youth (30 F/30M) engaged in training on local governance development issues 5. Finalized and approved AWP 2015 6. At least four case stories developed and shared each quarter 7. At least 8 visits paid to various location of the project 8. risks and issues updated quarterly for the project 9. LGDPEM Project experience produced by experts

1. 2 training workshop conducted in Gedarif State for new government executives on core local governance functions 2. 65 staff were trained on project management in Gedarif State (35 males and 30 female) represented from Ministry of Finance. 3. 70 youth (4 F/30M) were trained in Kassala State on electronic data management 4. 40 staff (22 males and 18 females) were trained on SPSS data analysis for in Ministry of Finance in Gedarif State. 5. 6 staff from East Sudan (Kassala, Red Sea and Gedarif states) participated in a study tour in Ethiopia, and were exposed to the planning, revenue mobilization and public finance management in Ethiopia. 6. 4 monitoring visits paid to various location of the project. 7. Project risks and issues updated in ATLAS 8. Impact study of the LGDPEM Project conducted in Kassala state as a case study.

1.1. Water harvesting and irrigation mechanisms are functional through rehabilitation of 2 wells and fitting with 15 solar pumps, and benefiting 100 farmers and pastoralists’ households In each state.
1.2.10% increase in average household income.

1.1. - 5 wells were rehabilated, 5 solar pumps were installed, and benefiting 100 farmers and pastoralists’ households In each state. 1.2. - 10% increase in average income was acheived 1.3. - 3 more knowledge products containing critical lessons learned and good adaptation practices from the four pilot agro-ecological zones

1,1 At least 3500 households form the small-scale farming and pastoral communities in 4 vulnerable regions or ecological zones (at least 50% women, including all women headed households. 1,2 20% Increase in yields and household incomes as a result of project implemented adaptation measures 1,3 High perception on the project contribution (More than 80%) 2.1 7 best practices documented and disseminated 2.2 At least 3 government programme or policy documents initiated adoption and upscale of project demonstrated adaptation successful practices.

1.1 A number of 3500 households in the four targeted areas have already been reached by the project’s various activities. 1.2 30-35% increase in average household income due to the increase in the production (animal and crops) was reported from the community members. (A structured survey will be conducted during Quarter 4 of this year to measure the actual percentage of increase). 1.3. title.narrative: Planning and Public Expenditure Management (PPEM) Darfur

description.narrative: The project aims at improving the State governments’ capacity to collect taxes and prioritize public expenditures. Improved public expenditure management with strengthened planning capacity will be instrumental in optimising delivery of public services.

The project aims at improving the State governments’ capacity to collect taxes and prioritize public expenditures. Improved public expenditure management with strengthened planning capacity will be instrumental in optimising delivery of public services.
seat of a first-order administrative division
Accountability - local government finance
1. Increase in revenue collection 2. Number of institutions at state and locality level with computerized payroll system 3. Number of SSP reviewed and prioritized for three states

comment.narrative: 1. Local revenue too low amounting to only 15% (ND), 20% (SD) and 3.5% (WD) of total revenue receipts in 2009 (ND) and 2010 (SD WD). 2. No Standard guidelines for revenue collection and reporting in place. 3. Budget departments facing difficulties to apply the GFS as it was imposed from the national Government without provision of requisite training. 4. Payroll is done manually resulting in errors and huge payroll arrears. 5. Strategic planning is still at its infancy and therefore needs strengthening.

1. 10% increase in local revenue collection 2. 100 booklets/guidelines developed distributed to localities 3. 10 teams applying GFS system in selected localities for the year 4. 10 line ministries and 10 selected localities prepare GFS conforming budget 5. 90 staff from line ministries and pilot localities trained on GFS. 6. 20% of line ministries and 20% of localities level decrease in reporting inconsistencies 7. 10 line ministries and 10 selected localities apply the adopted GFS system 8. 5 State Ministries of Finance equipped with computerized payroll system and routinely using it 9. 1 audit conducted 10. 20% decrease in payroll arrears 11. Guide for strategic planning developed 100 copies distributed 12. 200 staff at state and locality levels trained on strategic planning process.

1. 100 booklets have been developed and distributed to localities. The indicator is at 100% achievement rate. 2. The GFS refresher courses were implemented between months of October and December 2015 and a total of 130 staff (45 females and 85 males) (35% females and 65% males) from 29 Ministries of Finance and other line ministries and 20 localities were trained on applications using GFS 3. 13% so far. 130 staff (45 females and 85 males) (35% females and 65% males) from 19 ministries and 12 localities were trained on preparation of Final Accounts through the GFS. 4. 29 line ministries have been covered and 20 localities were supported with training on preparation of final government accounts and reporting. 295 staff (85 females and 207 males) were trained on financial management, financial auditing, internal auditing and modern trends in internal auditing 5. Three state ministries (North, South and West Darfur) are fully equipped and staff trained on the electronic payroll system Indicator attainment assessed at about 70% 6. Two preliminary audits were undertaken in West and South Darfur only. The high level commitment by the State Minister of Finance in Nyala was key in meeting this target. Indicator at 100% attainment rate.

1. 20% increase in state level local revenue collection 2. 10 teams (Darfur wide) applying GFS system in selected states and localities during 2016 3. 5 line ministries of finance in Darfur preparing GFS conforming budgets. 4. 25 staff from line ministries and localities applying skills in GFS during budget preparation 5. 50% Ministries of Finance have decreases in reporting inconsistencies 6. 3 line ministries and 5 selected localities apply the improved accounting and financial management and reporting skills 7. 5 payroll audits conducted (Darfur wide) 8. Two new State Ministries of Finance (East and Central Darfur) equipped with computerized payroll system and routinely using it 9. Staff from the ministries and civil society bottom up approaches to prepare state strategic plan

title.narrative: Capacity Dev for Aid Mgt and Coordination Phase II

description.narrative: Capacity Development for Aid Management and Coordination (Phase II)

title.narrative: Capacity Dev for Aid Mgt and

description.narrative: The project overall objective is to contribute to achieving aid effectiveness in Sudan through strengthening aid management and aid policy coordination
independent political entity

receiver-org.narrative: Government of Sudan, Republic of the

description.narrative:
Indicators Output1: 1.Number of government staff members o responsible for aid coordination functions whose capacities have significantly been improved 2.Improvement in organizational performance in units of MoFNE responsible for aid coordination (the organizational performance will be monitored through a capacity review in 2014) Indicators Output2: 1. Percentage of programmes included in SAID for which regularly updated ME data is available 2. Percentage of projects included in SAID for which regularly updated ME data is available
Indicators Output3:
1. Change in levels and quality of coordination of aid policy between government concerned departments (will be monitored through conducting aid policy coordination studies) 2. Establishment of sustainable government/development partners comprehensive dialogue forum on aid policy and coordination

comment.narrative:
Baseline output1: 1. Following the government restructure in 2012, the government Directorates responsible for aid management and coordination have been organized according to new institutional and coordination set up in the government. 2. Capacities of government officials responsible for aid management and coordination needs to be further developed to manage aid coordination after government restructuring 3. No comprehensive capacity assessment has been carried out for the government units and staff members responsible for aid management and coordination. 4. No comprehensive capacity development plan has been developed and implemented for the government units and staff members responsible for aid management and coordination
Baseline Output2: 1. SAID project module has been completed successfully. 2. SAID Fund Expectation module has been completed. 3. SAID programme and aid effectiveness modules have not been completed 4. Aid ME and information systems are not integrated and harmonized
Baseline Output3:
1. Government aid policy coordination between relevant directorates of the MoFNE (budget, policies, aid management and coordination and development directorates) needs strengthening especially after the government restructuring 2. There are no sufficient aid dialogue and coordination structures including government and development partners 3. A draft Sudan Aid Strategy has been formulated

1.Capacities of 200 key and junior government staff members responsible for aid coordination functions have significantly been improved Targets 2.1. 100% of programmes included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning ME system 2.2. 100% of projects included in SAID which are regularly updated from functioning ME system 2.3. SAID includes data on development loans 2.4. SAID available online 3.1. The Aid Strategy Document reviewed by government and development partners and endorsed 3.2. Terms of Reference and membership for sustainable government/development partners comprehensive dialogue forums on aid policy developed and coordination established 5.1. Study on “Strategic directions for peace building and sustainable development Darfur” completed. 5.2. Study on “society Status report 2014 is completed. 5.3. Concept paper on “fore sighting study for Sudan 2014-2030” is completed.

Indicator 1.1:
The project organized 3 training workshops at ElSaha Hotel in Khartoum, from the period of 26th April to 5th May 2016. The 3 workshops were attended by 135 participants from 16 states and focal points from core and line ministries at the federal level.
135 participants has been trained on the following workshops:
• Strategic Planning for 3 days from 26th - 28th April 2016 • Negotiation, Communication and Assertiveness for 2 days from 30th April – 1st May 2016 • Project Design and Proposal Writing for 4 days from 2nd – 5th May 2016
120 participants has been trained on SAID and Monitoring and Evaluation Systems as follows:
• The project has organized SAID and Monitoring Evaluation System in in North Kordofan and included participants from North, West and South Kordofan state from 13th – 14th November 2016. It was attended by 30 participants. • The second workshop has been organized on SAID and Monitoring and Evaluation System in Gezeria State to include participants from Geziera, Blue Nile and Sennar states from 16th – 17th November. It was attended by 30 participants. • The third workshop was organized for line and core ministries at the federal level from 5th – 6th December 2016 at Kanon Hotel in Khartoum. It was attended by 38 participants. • The fourth workshop was organized in Khartoum for participants from international organizations (bi-lateral and multi-lateral) at the federal level. It was attended by 18 participants. • The fifth workshop was organized in Khartoum for participants from Darfur states from 20th – 21st December 2016. It was attended by 22 participants.
Indicator 2.1: • Currently Sudan Aid Information Data Base (SAID) is undergoing development, review and updating process to include the development projects that were funded from grants up to first quarter of 2016; beta version is uploaded to a temporary website URL said.triblem.com for testing by all stakeholders from the government and the development partners till t

-- Change in government commitments, resource allocations and planning for the environmental and disaster risk management

comment.narrative: -- A number of consultative meetings with relevant stakeholders, academia and community held to discuss and agree on the methodology and structure of the national strategy -- Development of the national strategy started; national consultant recruited for this purpose. -- A team of consultants recruited to conduct risk assessment; produce risk profile for Sudan -- Remote Sensing Department of Khartoum University contracted to conduct the Risk Analysis and prepare Sudan Risk profile -- Hazard maps for floods prepared -- Early Warning equipment procured for the Early Warning Authority and Civil Defence Council
The draft strategy developed.
The strategy will be endorsed and approved by the Parliament and Council of Ministers.

policy, planning and administration

description.narrative: 1. Number of managerial, administrative technical personnel whose capacity is developed 2. Labour based coordination unit is in place with clear action plan and ToR 3. Number of workshops, conferences, meetings, etc., organized and held with governmental bodies, private sectors companies related to temporary job placement 4. comment.narrative: 1. Existing Poverty Unit at the MOHRDL 2. MOHRDL previous experience in Labour Intensive Programs

1. Labour based Coordination Unit established and well integrated within Ministry of Labour Administrative Reforms 2. Human technical capacity of Labour based Coordination Unit staff is developed 3. At least 2000 unskilled youth (700 male 300 female) trained in different skills 4. 75% of youth (50% male 25% female) absorbed into permanent employment

1. Labour based Coordination Unit is structured with 5 posts and assigned staff, namely Training and Curriculum Development; Policy, Planning and Research; Communications, Advocacy Resource Mobilization; and Youth Employment Business Advisory plus Head of the Unit. 2. A comprehensive Capacity Development Training plan has been developed which started by in – house trainings on Project Management and Microsoft Excel fundamentals. Technical trainings on the required areas of specialization for the Unit staff. i.e. Communication, Curriculum Design, Research and Youth Employment is to start by Jan 2016. 3. 1251 youth received training on waste management and entrepreneurship skills. 4.100 youth are offered permanent jobs at Waste Management Sector

Two Outputs: - Labour-Based Coordination Unit established within MOLAR, functional and operational - Capacities of unskilled young workers developed
Number of Target Beneficiaries: 2,000 unemployed unskilled and semi-skilled youth labourers in Khartoum State

1. The filing system (manual and electronic) is now functional with efficient classification of targeted groups, update to date record of training batches, categorization of employment opportunities and regular monitoring and tracking record of the youth. Thus far, the system has actual Data entry of 1,785 files (827 for Entrepreneurship and 958 for vocational training).The new application forms are under filtering and categorization process. 2. The third batch of Entrepreneurship Training completed for 73 youth, The first batch of the Vocational Training completed for 247 youth on vehicles mechanics, vehicles electricity, plumbing, interlock and vehicles driving, The total accumulative number of youth trained by the Project so far is 2,590 (1,238 on Waste Management, 1,105 on Entrepreneurship and 247 on Vocational training).. 3 The last batch of Entrepreneurship Training for around 700 youth, The second batch of the Vocational Training for 418 youth on vehicles mechanics, interlock and general electricity. and the last batch of Waste Management for 1,150 youth

comment.narrative:
?1. MFIs/Insurance companies ?have limited capacity to provide ?tailored financial services for ?smallholder rain-fed farmers and ?pastoralists. Current products are ?too generalized and do not ?consider flexible payment cycles ?and reasonable compensation ?criteria. MFIs/Insurance ?companies have not found means ?to access the remote, rural areas ??(e.g., mobile units), organize the ?farmers/pastoralists nor mitigate ?their associated risks. As a result, it ?is common that ?farmers/pastoralists use informal ?lending services. ?BASELINE:93,500 with access to ?MF, 0 with access to MF/WII; ?
?2.Existing budget plans do not ?have sufficient funds to maintain ?and operate environmental ?monitoring infrastructure. ?BASELINE: Annual OM budgets ?for weather and climate ?monitoring institutions are ?approximately, MoWRE: USD ??223,000, RSA: USD 100,000 ?and SMA: 300,000.? ?1.Currently, weather and ?climate monitoring ?coverage in the target ?States is limited. Most ?equipment is manual and ?up to 40% of equipment ?is not-functional. A ?BASELINE of what is ?operational includes in ?the 6 target States ?includes the following:? Meteorological stations: ??28 manual, 32 automatic Hydrology equipment: 17 ?water level, 4 manual and ??1 automatic flow meters? Rain gauges:? ?98 manual?
?2.There are existing ?regional and community-?based EWS initiatives for ?food security, however, a ?national alert system ?concerned with extreme ?hydro-meteorological ?phenomena is lacking. ? There is also a limited ?understanding of ?technical weather/climate ?information jargon (e.g., ?alerts are not translated ?into all national dialects). ?There is also no ?formalized ?communication ?mechanism for alerts and ?weather/climate ?information. End-users ?cannot provide feedback ?to improve the ?communication process.? BASELINE ?% Women who receive ?EWS alerts? states: 5%? ?% Men who receive EWS ?alerts/CI in target states: ??10%?
?3. BASELINE Bulletins are currently ?produced s

1.1: 50 % increase in population who have access to improved Early Warning System/Climate Information of whom at lease 50% are Women (farmers and pastoralists equally) received EWS alerts/CI in targeted states.

Procurement made during 2015 for outcome (1) devices and equipments are 30,7% of the WS (Automatic and manual), 98% of the rain gauges have been completed out of the 60% planned for 2015 for the institutional capacity of the SMA. %100 of the water level devises equipment have been purchased represents the whole procurement of the project for these items for the institutional capacity of MoWRIE by procuring Procurement of 8 water level meters to be placed, 3 manual, hydrological stations and 2 acoustic Doppler flow meters (ADCP).
1.1 The stations installed serving a total of 10,000 in River Nile covering 82,9% of the target population, of whom 3,300 are women (33%) and 15 rain gauges covered all the target villages. In North Kordofan state, all the target community are in Bara locality within the limits of the automatic station. the station serves 4,756 population, 1,198 are women representing (25,2%) In White Nile state the station has been installed in aldoaim locality where it serves 1,973 of the population 888 of them are women (45%) In South Darfur state, 32 units of the rain gauges have been delivered and 24 have been installed in 24 out of 26 target communities, and no automatic weather station have installed. The total coverage with the rain gages is (62%) representing 45,000 out of the total population of the target communities of South Darfur (71,564). In Kassala and Gedarif states the weather stations have not installed during this reporting period, and the rain gauges installed where 2 out of 42 delivered to the state office of SMA (4.8%) in Kassala and no unit installed in Gedarif. The total number of the rain gauges installed and function is 41 out of 162 planned for 2015 in the six states represents (25.3%). The total target population in the six states are 96,082, of them 25,386 (26.2% women) are covered with the target climate monitoring devices represents the farmer group have access to the climate/weather monitoring services in the target

1.1. 138,500 small-holder rain-fed farmers and pastoralists (SRFP) with access to MF and 45,000 SRFP with access to MF/WII (Disaggregation TBC) 1.2. 1.2. 30% (186,900 USD) increase in domestic financing for equipment/product operation and maintenance across all institutions (SMA, RSA, MoWRE, ARC 1.3. 1.2. 50 % increase in population who have access to improved EWS/CI (% Women who received EWS alerts/CI in target states: 8% % Men who receive EWS alerts/CI in target states: 15%; disaggregation by producer will be confirmed 1.3.2 Development of at least 2 tailored bulletins 1.3.3 Mobile Advisory Messages (SMS) 2. 1. At least one WII product piloted in 1 state 3.1. At least 3 flexible MF products developed which are geared towards the needs of rain-fed farmers and pastoralists 3.3. At least 3 adaptation technologies adopted by rain-fed farmers and pastoralists in the target states with 1 of these technologies targeting women or youth .4. 10% increase in yield and/or income for rain-fed farmers and pastoralists who have access to improved financial services linked with adaptation technologies 8% average increase in plants growth during early stages from flowering up to fruit stage, after that the season was collapsed due to the poor rainy season

1.1. During this reporting period, the CRF project has implemented number of results that will directly reduce the vulnerability of targeted communities and enhance climate resilience of rain fed farmer and pastoral groups. Such as: Increased climate monitoring and observation in the target communities by installing rain gauges and Automatic weather stations. Established knowledge sharing mechanism between NHMS institutions (SMA, RSA, MOWRIE) to provide relevant and accurate weather information on micro finance and micro insurance institutions. Conducted Series of training on vulnerability and climate adaptation done by the CRF project. Actual data for the assessment of relevant indicators will be generated late 2016 using same procedures as in the baseline. Development of WII products was based on farmer’s preference in six target states and has been presented to the stakeholders, accordingly 24 WII products have been developed for the farmers and pastoral groups. Technical and legal approval of these products is under progress. Alnilain insurance company has moved forward in securing the WII product approval form the company’s internal SHRIA committee. This allowed Alnilain insurance company to be the first to pilot the WII product. It has been agreed that the piloting of the WII product will be conducted during the winter season of 2016 in at least two of the six target states. This is expected to ease the process of the final technical and legal approval of the products by the relevant authorities.
1.2. The project partners (SMA, RSA, ARC and MoWRIE) have availed their office spaces and staff at the state and national levels to provide technical assistance for the project team and activities. Some activities have been implemented partially by the project partners such as the procurement and installation of the weather observation and monitoring devices and software by the SMA and RSA, water measurement devices by MoWRIE and the approved adaptation tec

comment.narrative: a) Renewable energy master plan b) Preliminary wind measurements have been carried out as well as some feasibility assessments based on those measurements. c) wind atlas based on extrapolation of world data with high probability of inaccuracy. d) Limited exchange of experiences with neighbouring countries with established wind farm like Egypt and Ethiopia. e) Number of MW power generated from wind energy. f) Number of wind farms developed in Sudan.

1.1) 2500 of young school dropouts and out of school trained on vocational entrepreneurial skills. 1.2) 2500 of young school dropouts and out of school trained on entrepreneurial skills

1.1 Progress: On Track. Follow-up/update meetings with the MoE and vocational training centres and schools conducted. Vocational training centres in the different states were identified and mapped. Labor market survey report acquired for Nyala, Elfashir and Eleneina. Registration for 2000 completed, 500 in each of South, East, West and Central. Data compilation and analyses done. Agreements were reached with the training centres in the five (5) Darfur States to provide counselling and vocational trainings for the target beneficiaries. Six (6) follow-up/update meetings with the Ministry of Education (MoE) and Vocational Training Centres (VTCs) and schools were conducted during the reporting period. 1.2 Progress: On Track. Advance steps taken; processes for enrolment of targets commenced. Contacts with the institutions to provide business development and entrepreneurial skills training have been established. The selection of implementing partners to provide the linkage with the existing vocational training institutes is in its final stages. 2.1: Progress On track. Business development service providers /centers were contacted, two (2) introductory meetings were held during which their capacities were assessed. Call for Proposal (CfP) was announced across all 5 states, and in response many humanitarian and development agencies submitted proposals for implementing the ALP project. The review of the proposals is currently on-going to engage implementing agencies.

1.1) Progress – on track. Construction of 2 police posts in central Darfur underway scheduled to be completed by end of January 2017. Construction of 1 police post in Kornoi locality in North Darfur completed. 1.2) Progress – on track. The target has already been exceeded. However, more training is foreseen targeting female police officers. Within the year, 291 police officers have been trained to date. 1.3) Progress – on track. Out of 291 policers trained, only 30 of them are female representing 10.3% of the total. The reason is that government post female police mainly to the urban areas due to the challenges of insecurity in the rural areas. Since these trainings took place in the rural areas, there are not many female police officers. Therefore those trained represent 100% of those available. 1.4) Progress – on track. This is delayed and efforts are being made to get stakeholders to actively record and document these incidents. 1.5) Progress – on track. Discussions held with GoS counterparts to ensure that a few centers are established and activated during the forthcoming reporting period, Equipment and materials for CPV already procured and delivered to the field. 1.6) Progress – on track. This activity has been delayed and planned to start early 2016. UNDP rule of law team has held meetings with the UNAMID on the plans to kick start. 1.7) Progress – on track. Preliminary discussions were held with UNAMID in El Fasher and also in Zalingei. The UNAMID Police team has made contacts with the UXO team in El Fasher and detailed discussions are envisaged in next quarter. No security and UXO assessments have been made under the auspices of this project. 1.8) Progress – Delayed. Advocacy efforts are on-going to ensure return concerns are captured in relevant policies and strategies. However, the development of the Return and Durable Solutions Strategies are yet to materialize.

title.narrative: Strengthening the Capacity of the Sudan National Human R

description.narrative: Strengthening the Capacity of the Sudan National Human Rights Commission

The project’s main objective is to support the SNHRC in the development of its operational, technical and legal capacities to become a cornerstone within Sudan’s national human rights protection system in line with the Paris Principles.

Output 1 Complaints management infrastructure strengthned
Indicators: 4.1. Mandate of Complaints committee reviewed/modified and Job classification of secretary reclassified as Registrar 4.2: Extent to which workflow design for Case management is completed for entire lifecycle of complaints 4:3: Development of operational policies for complaints management established 4.4: Development of Manuals (tools) for intake, investigations, referrals, reporting, urgent cases, confidentiality, and systemic cases . 4.5: Feasibility study developed/finalized on viable options for automated CM system 4.6: Caseload (quantity) of received is disaggerated equaly on gender baisis 4.7 . Duration of case processing by calaneder days. Output 5: Engagement in Darfur supported
Output 2: Engagement in Darfur supported
Indicators
2. 1: New committee on Darfur established and strategic priorities for Darfur defined 2.2: workshops on joint human rights cooperation framework conducted 23: of meetings of Darfur human rights forum 2.4: of meetings of State human rights sub-forums at the local level to address key human rights concerns
Indicators: output 3 Commissioners and staff capacity to perform respective functions through the delivery of targeted trainings and professional development:

comment.narrative:
1.1 Complaints Committee established and has begun working, but administrative staff acts as intake officer and registrar 1.2: There is no structured workflow for case management life cycle in SNHRC 1.3: No complaints management manual 1.4: No feasibility study has been conducted 1,5 No automated case management system in place 1.6 Gender disaggregation of caseload is currently 20% female and 80% males cases 1.7 . TBC
Baseline out 2:
2.1: No committee on Darfur established and strategic priorities for Darfur not defined 2.2: No engagement of SNHRC in joint human rights cooperation framework 2.3: Zero 2.4: No systematic engagement or activities in Darfur
Baseline output3:
3.1. Zero staff trained 3.2. Zero operational policy is in place

4.1: Complaints committee reviewed to assumes oversight and governance role; position of registrar established 4.2: Complaints management process flow is designed for entire case management life cycle 4.3: Caseload processing manuals are developed for intake, investigations, referrals, reporting, urgent cases, confidentiality, and systemic cases 4..4 Feasibility study on CM finalized 4.5 Automated case management system installed and in place 4.6 Gender disaggregation of caseload become 50% female and 50% males cases 4.7 . TBE
Targets for Output 2:
2.1: Special committee on Darfur in place and Strategic priorities for Darfur set 2: 2 One workshop on joint human rights cooperation framework 2.3 Four meetings of the Darfur Human Rights Forum with Gos, ACHR, SNHRC, donors, UN agencies, CSOs 2.4: Ten meetings at the local level to address key human rights concerns
Targets for Output 3:
3.1. All staff (112 staff 40% of whom are females ) received training on core operational policies; At least 10 trainings courses conducted on case management. 3.2. TBC (Key internal administrative and operational policies in place)

Overall progress of output 4: Complaint Management infrastructure strengthened: internal regulations of the Complaints Committee revised with oversight and governance role of the Complaints Committee, with Complaints Manual and standard forms covering the management process for the entire life cycle of a case have been developed. In order to increase the visibility of the SNHRC and of the Complaints Committee in particular, an outreach programme was organized for 70 people, including over 10 members of the media.
Overall Progress of Output 5 Engagement in Darfur: Workshop was organized in Khartoum with representatives from Darfur, UNAMID Human rights Section to establish the new Committee on Darfur and define its road map or strategic plan for the opening of the SNHRC in Darfur, and arrangements are underway to launch the Darfur Branch in December
Overall Progress of output 6: Commissioners and staff capacity to perform respective functions through the delivery of targeted training and professional developed: Significant results have been achieved in developing internal policies. A two-day training for the Commissioners and the staff of the Complaints Committee was held, and 7 operational policies were developed: 1 internal regulation and 3 key operational procedures for the Complaints Committee (as annexes to the Complaints Manual) ; 1 ethics/conflict of interest policy; 1 Staff Recruitment policy; 1 job description template

1. Feasibility study on Complaint Management finalized 2. Automated case management system installed and operational 3. Gender dis-aggregation of caseload (50% female and 50% males) 4. Four meetings of the Darfur Human Rights Forum with GoS, ACHR, SNHRC, donors, UN agencies, CSOs 7. Four meetings at the local level to address key human rights concerns 8. The feasibility of automated software assessed, and training conducted on new policies and software.

receiver-org.narrative: Government of Sudan, Republic of the

description.narrative: project document prepared

comment.narrative: Various ad-hoc efforts are being made by different government entities such as the Ministry of Water Resources, Electricity and Irrigation, which has an initiative to replace one million Incandescent Lamps (ICLs 60-100W) with high-quality, long life (10,000 hours) energy efficient Compact Fluorescent Lamps (CFL). In line with electricity efficiency efforts, the Sudanese Standards and Meteorology Organization (SSMO) is establishing a laboratory for testing performance of all electrical appliances. Different electrical appliance performance testing equipment have been procured and are expected to be installed by December 2015. The Electricity Regulatory Authority is also keen on developing new regulatory measures for EE; at present the country has no MEPS for any appliances or equipment. Moreover the Arab Regional Center for Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency (RCREEE) initiated a series of workshops targeting public utilities, companies, universities and other stakeholders on developing the capacities for promoting energy efficiency actions.
Recruitment of consultants and start project preparation
International consultant and two national consultants were recruited to develop the project document.
Prepare the project document of the Leapfrogging Sudan’s markets to efficient appliances

comment.narrative: Zero

1. 3000 least advantaged young community members in 3 states (between 500 to 1000 youth in each state) are trained on different vocational and entrepreneurial skills 2. 3000 least advantaged young community members in 3 states (between 500 to 1000 youth in each state) temporarily employed 3. At least 30 community based business groups (5 to 10 in each state) formed 4. At least 30 community based business groups received enrolled into saving and credit schemes through Autonomous Saving and Credit Association 5. At least top 30 community based business groups received start-up micro-grants 6. 30 of community members business groups supported through Business Support Services in the 3 states 7. 20 of community members business groups benefited from additional

Q2 (July – September 2016) 1- A total number of 1,914 of the beneficiaries in the three States have started their vocational trainings mainly in the areas of auto mechanics, auto and general electricity, plumbing, driving, food processing, handicrafts, henna tattooing and tailoring. 2- A total number of 1,358 beneficiary in the three states have engaged in temporary labour in 5 sectors: water networking, unskilled support technicians, self-income generating activities, heavy machinery driving, heavy machinery control and apprentices in small workshops. 3- A number of 480 in Red Sea State have been formed into groups and enrolled into saving scheme through their bank accounts, and groups’ formation has actively started in Kassala and Gadaref states. 4- A number of 358 beneficiaries in Kassala (241) and Gedarif States (117) are engaged in self-generating income activities like producing biscuits, cookies, other bakery or handicraft products and started saving up to SDG 2,000 in less than two weeks.
